dataset/provenance: The dataset used in this study was sourced from patients with mesial temporal lobe epilepsy (MTLE) who underwent surgical treatment. A total of 104 patients were enrolled, with 93 patients in the training/validation set and 11 patients in the test set. The training/validation set included 45 patients with left MTLE and 48 with right MTLE, while the test set included 4 patients with left MTLE and 7 with right MTLE. The dataset consisted of 18F-FDG PET scans and MPRAGE images, which were processed using MATLAB and SPM12 software. The study utilized two personalized atlases: the parcellated Automated Anatomical Labeling (AAL) atlas using DARTEL and the aparc + aseg atlas from FreeSurfer. These atlases were used to extract normalized PET uptake values from specific regions of interest (ROIs), including the hippocampus and MTLE-associated regions. The dataset was analyzed to determine the lateralization of the epileptogenic side in MTLE patients, with the goal of improving preoperative diagnosis and surgical outcomes. The study also compared the performance of different machine learning classifiers in predicting the lateralization of MTLE. The dataset was analyzed using statistical methods, including Mann-Whitney U tests and Fisher exact tests, and the results were validated using 10-fold cross-validation. The study protocol was approved by the Institutional Review Board of Taipei Veterans General Hospital, and all clinical investigations were conducted according to the principles expressed in the Declaration of Helsinki.
dataset/splits:
In our study, we utilized two primary data splits: a training/validation set and a test set. The training/validation set consisted of 93 patients, with 45 having left mesial temporal lobe epilepsy (MTLE) and 48 having right MTLE. This cohort included 35 males and 58 females. The median seizure onset age was 13 years, and the median age at surgery was 34 years. After surgery, 2 patients were lost to follow-up within 2 years, leaving 91 patients who completed the postsurgical outcome evaluation. Among these, 77 patients achieved Engel classification I seizure outcomes, indicating a significant improvement.

The test set comprised 11 patients, with 4 having left MTLE and 7 having right MTLE. This smaller cohort included 4 males and 7 females, with a median seizure onset age of 18 years. Surgical outcomes at 2 years were followed in 5 patients. There were no significant differences in sex, lesion side, onset age, age at operation or sEEG evaluation, seizure duration, or surgical outcome between the patients in the training/validation set and those in the test set. This distribution ensured a robust evaluation of our machine learning models, allowing for both training and independent validation of the results.

optimization/encoding:
The data encoding and preprocessing for the machine-learning algorithm involved several steps. Initially, the original DICOM file format of the 18F-FDG PET and MPRAGE images was converted into the 3D NIfTI-1 file format, which is compatible with the Statistical Parametric Mapping program SPM12. This conversion facilitated subsequent image preprocessing.

The next step involved resetting the image orientation of the 18F-FDG PET and MPRAGE images to roughly align with the anterior commissure of the individual brain space. This alignment improved the registering performance between the 18F-FDG PET and MPRAGE images in SPM12.

Following this, the 18F-FDG PET image was registered to the MPRAGE image using 3D voxel registration based on the normalized mutual information method. The MPRAGE image was then segmented into a brain tissue probability map, including gray matter, white matter, and cerebrospinal fluid.

Intensity normalization of the 18F-FDG PET images was performed using the whole-brain gray matter as a reference region. The intensity-normalized 18F-FDG PET image was then spatially smoothed with a Gaussian smoothing kernel of 8 mm full width at half maximum.

Two personalized atlases were created: the parcellated Automated Anatomical Labeling (AAL) atlas using DARTEL and the aparc + aseg atlas from FreeSurfer. These atlases encompassed the anatomical labels used to extract the normalized PET standardized uptake value of the regions of interest (ROIs). The mean standardized uptake value (SUV) of each ROI was obtained by dividing the uptake count by the whole cerebral gray matter. For each subject, the corresponding mean uptake values of 18F-FDG PET were calculated for bilateral ROIs. Additionally, the lateralization index was calculated for each ROI, defined as 2/(L − R)/(L + R), where L and R represent the uptake values for the left and right hemispheres, respectively.

The lateralization indices for the parcellated AAL atlas and the aparc + aseg atlas were then submitted to the training/validation set model for classification of patients' MTLE sides. Seven machine learning models, including decision trees, discriminant analysis, logistic regression classifiers, naive Bayes classifiers, support vector machines, nearest neighbor classifiers, and ensemble classifiers, were used to train the model. 10-fold cross-validation was employed to establish the classification model using the classification learner app of MATLAB. The model with the best validation accuracy score was selected for further clinical application.

optimization/regularization:
In our study, we employed several techniques to prevent overfitting and ensure the robustness of our machine learning models. One of the primary methods used was 10-fold cross-validation. This technique involves dividing the dataset into 10 subsets, training the model on 9 of these subsets, and validating it on the remaining subset. This process is repeated 10 times, with each subset serving as the validation set once. By averaging the results, we obtained a more reliable estimate of the model's performance and reduced the risk of overfitting to any single subset of the data.

Additionally, we utilized multiple machine learning classifiers, including decision trees, discriminant analysis, logistic regression classifiers, naive Bayes classifiers, support vector machines, nearest neighbor classifiers, and ensemble classifiers. The diversity of these models helped to mitigate the risk of overfitting by ensuring that our results were not dependent on a single algorithm's idiosyncrasies.

Furthermore, we compared the performance of two different atlases: the parcellated AAL atlas using DARTEL and the aparc + aseg atlas from FreeSurfer. This comparison provided an additional layer of validation, as the models were tested across different anatomical parcellations, reducing the likelihood of overfitting to a specific atlas configuration.

In summary, our approach to preventing overfitting included the use of 10-fold cross-validation, a variety of machine learning classifiers, and the comparison of different anatomical atlases. These methods collectively enhanced the generalizability and reliability of our findings.

model/interpretability:
The model developed in this study is not a blackbox. It leverages machine learning classifiers to analyze specific anatomical regions of interest (ROIs) in 18F-FDG PET scans, which are clearly defined and based on established atlases. Two personalized atlases were used: the AAL atlas parcellated using DARTEL and the aparc + aseg atlas from FreeSurfer. These atlases encompass anatomical labels that are relevant for extracting normalized PET uptake values from specific ROIs, particularly those associated with mesial temporal lobe epilepsy (MTLE).

The ROIs for the AAL atlas include the superior orbital frontal gyrus, middle orbital frontal gyrus, inferior orbital frontal gyrus, insula, posterior cingulate gyrus, hippocampus, parahippocampus, amygdala, thalamus, temporal pole of superior temporal gyrus, and temporal pole of middle temporal gyrus. For the aparc + aseg atlas, the ROIs include the thalamus, hippocampus, amygdala, entorhinal, lateral orbital gyrus, medial orbital gyrus, posterior cingulate gyrus, temporal pole, insular gyrus, parahippocampus, superior temporal gyrus, middle temporal gyrus, and inferior temporal gyrus.

The mean standardized uptake value (SUV) of each ROI is obtained by dividing the uptake count by the whole cerebral gray matter. The lateralization index for each ROI is calculated using the formula 2/(L + R) * (L - R)/(L + R), where L and R represent the uptake values for the left and right hemispheres, respectively. This index helps in determining the side of MTLE epileptogenesis.

The model uses these clearly defined ROIs and their corresponding uptake values to train and validate various machine learning classifiers, including decision trees, discriminant analysis, logistic regression classifiers, naive Bayes classifiers, support vector machines, nearest neighbor classifiers, and ensemble classifiers. The performance of these classifiers is evaluated using 10-fold cross-validation, and the model with the best validation accuracy is selected for further clinical application.

The transparency of the model is further enhanced by the use of a graphical user interface (GUI), which allows for the incorporation of this method into clinical practice. The GUI facilitates the artificial intelligence (AI) analysis of FDG PET scans, making the process more accessible and interpretable for clinicians. This approach ensures that the model's decisions are based on well-defined anatomical regions and measurable uptake values, providing a clear and interpretable basis for lateralizing the side of MTLE epileptogenesis.
model/output: The model developed in this study is a classification model. It is designed to determine the lateralization of the epileptogenic side in patients with mesial temporal lobe epilepsy (MTLE) using 18F-FDG PET data. The model utilizes machine learning classifiers to analyze the normalized PET uptake of specific regions of interest (ROIs) and classify the data into lateralization epileptogenic foci. Several machine learning algorithms, including decision trees, discriminant analysis, logistic regression classifiers, naive Bayes classifiers, support vector machines, nearest neighbor classifiers, and ensemble classifiers, were employed. The model's performance was evaluated using 10-fold cross-validation, and the classifier with the best validation accuracy score was selected for further clinical application. The output of the model provides an accuracy rate for classifying the side of MTLE epileptogenesis, with the nearest neighbor classifier achieving the highest accuracy of 96.8% for the parcellated AAL atlas and the support vector machine classifier achieving 95.7% for the aparc + aseg atlas. In the test set, both the nearest neighbor classifier for the parcellated AAL atlas and the support vector machine classifier for the aparc + aseg atlas attained an accuracy rate of 100.00%.
model/duration: The execution time for the model varied depending on the method used. The DARTEL method had a significantly shorter computing time, taking approximately 25 minutes. This method could be performed on both Windows and MacOS systems, making it more versatile for different clinical environments. In contrast, the FreeSurfer method required a longer computing time of about 6 hours. Despite the difference in execution times, both methods demonstrated similar performance in terms of accuracy. The shorter execution time of the DARTEL method makes it more practical for clinical use, allowing for quicker processing and integration into routine workflows.

evaluation/method:
The evaluation of the machine-assisted classifier involved several steps to ensure its accuracy and reliability. Initially, the performance of different machine learning classifiers was assessed using a training/validation set consisting of 93 patients. The classifiers were evaluated based on their ability to lateralize the epileptogenic side in mesial temporal lobe epilepsy (MTLE) using two different parcellation methods: the DARTEL method and the aparc + aseg atlas from FreeSurfer. The nearest neighbor classifier achieved the highest accuracy of 96.8% with the parcellated AAL atlas using DARTEL, while the support vector machine classifier attained the best accuracy of 95.7% with the aparc + aseg atlas.

To further validate the model, a test set of 11 patients was used. The nearest neighbor classifier model for the parcellated AAL atlas using DARTEL achieved an accuracy rate of 100.00% in the test set. Similarly, the support vector machine classifier model for the aparc + aseg atlas also attained an accuracy rate of 100.00% in the test set. This high accuracy in the test set indicates the robustness and generalizability of the model.

Additionally, the study evaluated the performance of the machine-assisted classifier in patients whose PET asymmetry could not be lateralized by visual analysis. For these 23 patients, the analysis of MTLE-associated regions provided better lateralization compared to the hippocampus alone. The DARTEL method showed an advantage over the FreeSurfer method in these cases, correctly lateralizing the side of MTLE epileptogenesis in 100.0% of the patients when using the MTLE-associated ROI model.

The evaluation also included a comparison of the machine-assisted method with traditional visual analysis. The accuracy of visual analysis by three physicians was 75.3%, which is lower than the accuracy achieved by the machine-assisted classifiers. This highlights the superior performance of the machine-assisted method in lateralizing the epileptogenic side in MTLE patients.

In summary, the evaluation method involved a comprehensive assessment using a training/validation set, a test set, and a comparison with traditional visual analysis. The high accuracy rates achieved in both the validation and test sets, along with the superior performance in challenging cases, demonstrate the effectiveness and reliability of the machine-assisted classifier for lateralizing the epileptogenic side in MTLE patients.
evaluation/measure:
In our study, we evaluated the performance of various machine learning classifiers for lateralizing the epileptogenic side in mesial temporal lobe epilepsy (MTLE) patients using FDG PET data. The primary performance metric reported is accuracy, which is expressed as a percentage. This metric indicates the proportion of correctly classified cases out of the total number of cases.

For classifiers based on associated regions of interest (ROIs), the accuracy ranged from 88.2% to 96.8% across different models. The nearest neighbor classifier achieved the highest accuracy of 96.8% using the parcellated AAL atlas, while the support vector machine classifier attained the best accuracy of 95.7% using the aparc + aseg atlas. These results demonstrate the high effectiveness of machine-assisted classification in lateralizing MTLE.

When the analysis was limited to the hippocampus as the sole ROI, the accuracy ranged from 91.4% to 95.7%. The support vector machine classifier performed best, achieving an accuracy of 95.7% in both the parcellated AAL atlas and the aparc + aseg atlas. This indicates that even with a single ROI, the classifiers can achieve high accuracy, though slightly lower than when using multiple associated ROIs.

In the test set, the nearest neighbor classifier and the support vector machine classifier both achieved a perfect accuracy rate of 100.00%. This outstanding performance in the test set further validates the robustness and reliability of the machine-assisted classification approach.

The accuracy metrics reported in this study are representative of the current literature on machine learning applications in medical imaging. The high accuracy rates achieved, particularly in the test set, suggest that the proposed method is highly effective and could significantly aid in the preoperative diagnosis of epilepsy surgery. The use of multiple classifiers and the comparison of different atlases provide a comprehensive evaluation of the method's performance, ensuring its reliability and generalizability.
evaluation/comparison:
In our study, we compared the performance of two different methods for segmenting brain regions: the DARTEL method and FreeSurfer segmentation. Both methods were used to obtain a lateralization index from 18F-FDG PET data, which was then analyzed using various machine learning classifiers.

The performance of these methods was evaluated using a dataset of patients with mesial temporal lobe epilepsy (MTLE). The accuracy of the classifiers was similar for both methods, with the nearest neighbor classifier achieving the highest accuracy of 96.8% for the parcellated AAL atlas using DARTEL, and the support vector machine classifier achieving 95.7% accuracy for the aparc + aseg atlas from FreeSurfer.

In terms of practical considerations for clinical use, the DARTEL method has advantages such as shorter computing time (25 minutes compared to 6 hours for FreeSurfer) and compatibility with both Windows and MacOS systems. Additionally, we developed a graphical user interface (GUI) to facilitate the incorporation of this method into clinical practice.

While we did not compare our methods to publicly available benchmark datasets, our focus was on evaluating the performance of these segmentation methods within the context of our specific clinical application. The comparison to simpler baselines was not explicitly performed, as our primary goal was to assess the effectiveness of these methods in aiding the preoperative diagnosis of epilepsy surgery using 18F-FDG PET scans.
evaluation/confidence:
The evaluation of our machine learning classifiers involved a rigorous statistical analysis to ensure the robustness and reliability of our results. We employed 10-fold cross-validation to assess the performance of our models, which provided a comprehensive estimate of their accuracy and generalizability. The performance metrics, including accuracy, were evaluated across different classifiers and atlases, with the nearest neighbor classifier and support vector machine achieving the highest accuracy rates.

Statistical significance was determined using appropriate tests, such as the Mann-Whitney U test and Fisher exact test, to compare continuous and categorical variables between groups. The level of statistical significance was set at P < 0.05, ensuring that our findings were not due to random chance. For instance, the accuracy of the nearest neighbor classifier model in the test set was 100.00%, indicating a highly significant result.

Confidence intervals were not explicitly mentioned for the performance metrics, but the use of cross-validation and statistical tests provides a strong foundation for the reliability of our results. The consistent high accuracy across different models and the statistical significance of our findings support the claim that our machine-assisted classifier is superior to traditional visual analysis methods. The comparison with visual analysis, which showed lower accuracy and higher variability, further underscores the superiority of our approach.
